title: Google News - Health - Fitness
description: Read full articles, watch videos, browse thousands of titles and more on the 'Health' topic with Google News.

items.title: Exercising while sick? Know when it’s okay to work out and when to skip
items.content_text: Exercising during illness might not be the best thing to do. Your immunity takes a hit and it can be uncomfortable for you to exercise. Let's find out who can still exercise even if they are sick.
items.content_html: Exercising during illness might not be the best thing to do. Your immunity takes a hit and it can be uncomfortable for you to exercise. Let's find out who can still exercise even if they are sick.

items.title: Surprising link between exercise and negative memory bias discovered
items.content_text: New research has found that a single bout of exercise is not sufficient to relieve memory bias or rumination, rather it may even aggravate these depressotypic cognitive processes in some individuals. ...

items.title: Can coffee make you walk 1,000 extra steps but rob you of sleep? Does it impact diabetes? What new study means
items.content_text: Caffeine is good for endurance exercises and as a stimulant, ups your alertness, cutting into your sleep time. But keep to a moderate intake of up to four cups a day to avoid adverse effects, says Dr Ajay Aggarwal, Director and Head, Internal Medicine, Fortis Hospital, Noida

items.title: AHA, ACC Advocate Supervised Exercise Training in HFpEF

items.title: Benefits Of Stretching Exercise: Why It Is Important To Include Stretching In Your Daily Routine, Watch Video
items.content_text: Stretching exercises have numerous benefits for the body and the mind. First and foremost, stretching helps improve flexibility and range of motion, reducing the risk of injury during physical activities. Stretching also promotes circulation and helps release muscle tension, reducing soreness and stiffness. TheHealthSite.com
items.content_html: Stretching exercises have numerous benefits for the body and the mind. items.title: Add Some 'Chaos' to Your Training with these 4 Instability Moves
items.content_text: Adding instability to your weight training in the form of unstable surfaces or reducing points of contact was all the rage a while ago. But mixed with social media and the fight for eyeballs, some may have taken creativity a bit too far. It was (and still can) more circus trick than strength training. And…
